As the climate continues to warm, we can expect an increased occurrence of browning across the Arctic Coastal Plain of northern Alaska (Figs 2 and 5), but the rate at which the landscape browns, depends on the magnitude of temperature and precipitation change (Fig. 4), with the exception of young geomorphic types from recently drained lakes (e.g. nonpatterned drained thaw lake basins and low-center polygons) that will likely continue to green. These patterns were highlighted in our analysis as historical NDVI trends varied by tundra geomorphic type (Fig. 3). Browning was particularly sensitive to elevated temperature and/or precipitation (Table 2), both of which are predicted to increase across arctic tundra regions
